There are lots of comments here about the possible relevance of this phenomenon to the formation of the eukaryotic cell. Current research tells us that the endomembrane systems of eukaryotes, and in particular the nucleus with its elaborate nuclear pore complex, are not found in archaea, and seem to be derived, at least in part, from bacterial ancestral components. These findings seem to be best compatible with a symbiogenesis scenario for the origin of eukaryotes under which eukaryogenesis was triggered by the endosymbiosis of an α-proteobacterium with an ancestral archaeon, with the nucleus evolving as a defense against intron invasion. That is to say the ancestors of the eukaryotes were prokaryotes and viruses are not part of the picture. That picture, however, is far from complete. I'd like to see a SciShow video about this matter. https://genomebiology.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/gb-2010-11-5-209

This weirdass thing right here begs the question: "Is the body the living thing, or are the genes what's truly alive?". By every definition I've ever seen, viruses are not considered alive, due to a lack of homeostasis. However, if they're able to replicate, mutate (and by chance, adapt/evolve), and even develop complex structures when beneficial, over time, one might say otherwise.
So basically, if one treats the genes as a living thing, the living thing has developed a way to produce chemical structures and aid its survival and reproduction. It's just sorta skipping some steps to use someone else's shell to do it in, which is hecking bizarre.

I think that it is amazing that viruses seem so simple but are still so potent pathogens! HIV and other so-called retroviruses, for example, are able to integrate their genome into our DNA (in this manner, they remain much longer, I just made a video explaining retroviruses and HIV in greater detail).In fact, over 44% of our genome contains former retroviral sequences. The weird thing is that they sometimes can be reactivated and mess with our genome, thereby causing different autoimmune diseases. Weird but still amazing!
